narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Introduction to microeconomics...
Basic understanding of fundamental microeconomics.  Learned how to engage with material in a big lecture setting.
Introductory to microeconomics
Basic Econ skills, and knowledge about firms, monopolies, oligopolies.
Deeper understanding of markets, competition, producer theory, consumer theory, social welfare, efficiency,  game theory, and an introduction to economics research.
I learned a basic understanding of introductory microeconomics. The concepts are not very interesting, but some basic understanding of economics is nice to know.
It's a good introduction to econ for someone who has never taken econ before. There's a little bit of math and a little bit of social studies/memorization.

I learned that when they tell you that the curve is good they are lying. The curve kept me from failing and gave me a B-range grade, however, in terms of actually doing well in the class that did not happen for me. I learned that graphs, which are seemingly rather simple, become extraordinarily complicated when it comes to economics. I loved the concepts in this class and found them very interesting, however, the mathematics portion of this class did not connect to those concepts in a coherent way. The math kept me from enjoying this course. The math portion was not taught well. Additionally the teaching fellows were super hard to follow as they did not know how to explain how concepts connected to math.
I learned the basics of microeconomics, which is basically markets, how individuals act in the market, firms and consumers etc.
A general overview of microeconomics as well as specific insights into taxation, dead weight loss and the different forms of market competition.
I learned about the basics of microeconomic theory. When taught by Professor O'Dea, the course dives into some public economics and explores the shortcomings of the models covered.
Comprehensive understanding of intro micro.
Learned microeconomics
I learned about micro economics.
Everything I needed to know about introductory microeconomics-  it taught me a new way to think- especially when making decisions in real life situations.
An insight into microeconomics.
Basic knowledge of microeconomics and some of its applications in everyday life.
The insights behind my maximizing my returns on my everyday decisions.
This introductory Econ course was really interesting. I found the information to be very engaging and fun to learn. You focus on producer theory, consumer theory, and market failures.
basic econ and graphing
I developed the ability to "think like an economist" and solve basic microeconomics problems.

how to apply an economic analysis to a firm's behavior and performance in the market, how to visually depict supply/demand, costs, monopolies, oligopolies etc., knowledge of basic economic terms/concepts, quantitative thinking and problem-solving
Lots of insight into economics and market structure
great introduction to microeconomics
i learned many new econ concepts
I learned a lot about economic graphs and how to think about microeconomics.
Micro econ topics and conbcepts. Great Intro to the subject!
Microeconomics- supply, demand, properties of the market, market equilibrium, etc.
Learned the basics of Microeconomics
This was a great intro course to econ. I had no background in econ and came away feeling confident in the topics we covered.
I learned fundamental micro-economic thought and how to think like an economist.
Basic Microecon stuff (i.e. supply demand, cost-production, marginal analysis, monopoly, oligopoly, basic game theory, etc)
The class was a great revision even though I took AP Micro in high school and there were a decent number of concepts I had not learned before.
I obtained a basic knowledge of economics.
I learned about supply and demand, perfect competition, duopoly, monopoly, and producer and consumer theory. I learned how to think like an economist.
Applications to real world
Micro economics
Understanding about microeconomics, supply and demand, utility, markets and power
I developed an method of thinking like an economist.
This course made Econ actually interesting to me. Professor is great!
Basic skills of working out profits for firms.
I learned a ton of skills in relation to problem solving and economics!
I developed many core Econ skills and loved the professor!
Understanding the market and consumer and producer theory of the supply and the demand curve and countless other material
I learned the basics of microeconomics.
I learned the basics of microeconomics and how to consider the role of producers, consumers, and other factors in a market.

Microeconomics is an extremely valuable tool with which to access the world. You learn about markets, supply and demand, and some basic economic theory. I think this course is wonderful in that it helped me understand some basics of life. That said, it should not be confused as normative theory, and this economics course did a great job of making sure that economics was used as a means rather than an end.
I think that I learned a lot about microeconomics, such as firm behaviors and market types.
Nothing done it all before
Economic skills

This course obviously teaches the basics in economic theory: law supply and demand, produced theory, consumer theory, and we also got into some game theory and market failures. I also learned a fair amount about just generally how businesses and markets function as well as what economists actually do.
Learned a solid introduction to microeconomics
Basic skills pertaining to introductory microeconomics (supply and demand, monopoly, cournot competition)
I learned a lot about the basics of microeconomics. I learned that I am actually interested in economics and will pursue further courses!
I learned valuable information on core concepts and principles of Microeconomics.
This course gives a good overview of the concept of microeconomics.
How to study from slides, intuition
Great understanding of intro to microeconomics, second half was difficult

I broadly learned skills from Economic skills at insight. Specifically, this gave me a good intuitive understanding of fundamental economic concepts which will provide useful in more advanced Econ classes.
I gained an understanding of introductory microeconomics (supply and demand, how taxes affect consumers and firms, market efficiency, etc.).
A sufficient understanding of the basic principles of microeconomics, problem solving and critical thinking skills.

This was a great introduction to the world of economics, and we learned how to navigate both the consumer and supplier sides of decision making, along with some introduction to public economics and game theory.
How the economy works, how individual consumers and firms act, how marginal analysis works
I learned the basics of consumer and producer theory in great detail. I also felt that I developed the basic framework of marginal analysis skills.
I learned how to think like an economist, and how to view the world with this set of tools.
I gained a new perspective on how markets function and how competing interests result in market outcomes. It's an interesting survey on basic economics concepts.
I learned introductory microeconomics concepts, starting with basic ideas like supply and demand and ending with more complex things like game theory.
I developed a basic knowledge for microeconomics and an understanding about the study of economics.
Analytical

I learned the basics of consumer and producer theory, including supply and demand, taxes, constraints, and game theory. I have started to think about how producers and consumers make choices based on the supply and demand curve and their constraints, broadening my perspectives of the microeconomy.
How to think in an economics mindset
Consumer theory, producer theory, basic game theory
Critical thinking and understanding graphs
How to study farther in  advance.
I developed an understanding of microeconomics and the intricacies of supply and demand.
I learned some fundamentals of microeconomics and the application to markets in the real world.
Basic economic theory
Great Econ foundation

While taking this course, I learned more about how individuals firms (producers) and consumers make decisions and why they make these decisions. I learned more about how the economy as a whole functions and why markets function the way they do.,
I learned the quantitative skills necessary to understand decisions in the market. I also learned how to fend for myself in a large class like econ.
I learned the basics of Micro Economics.
We learned about consumer and producer theory, market structures, the role that government plays in the economy, and formalization of economic intuitions, both mathematical and graphical.
I gained a vast amount of general knowledge regarding economics. I learned how to interpret economic data and apply economic concepts/logic to everyday, real world problems.
supply and demand

I learned about how to approach life as a consumer with more knowledge, and I learned about the ways in which markets function. This was was also my first introduction to understanding how economists view economic policies, and understanding the dilemma summed up in the equity-efficiency tradeoff.
Gained a solid understanding of microeconomics: consumer theory, producer theory, costs, externalities, and more. Relevant to understanding government, society, and more econ in the future
Theoretical fundamental concepts of microeconomics
I learned how to think about opportunity costs in normal life and not to worry about sunk costs. I learned how demand and supply control a firm and a market.
I learned the basics of microeconomics.
Basic introduction microeconomics. Supply, Demand, Elasticity, Externalities, Taxes, Utility and more.
basic consumer and producer theory, basic game theory

This course taught the basics of consumer and producer behavior, with a focus on mathematical analysis and some discussion of policy considerations. It showed me how simple models can be used to reach broad and sometimes unexpected conclusions that closely resemble real outcomes, but also how these models can be flawed. The course also discussed what economic results are statements of fact, and which rest on individual judgements or values. A unit on market failures was included, but was very brief.
I learned microeconomics.
Basic econ
i understood a little bit more of the basics of how the world works. the practicality and applicability made me want to take more econ.

How important economics is for social welfare and political issues, basics of economics such as supply and demand, consumer and producer theory, profit maximization and cost minimization, the difference between market s & d and firm supply and demand.
I got a basic idea of the foundations of economics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lecture was a lot better than I expected because of Prof. O'Dea! The concepts he taught made sense most of the time, and he really tried to tie the concepts to economics problems in real life, which was really interesting. Section was not that helpful, I found peer tutoring to be more helpful for help on the psets.
Professor did a good job structuring daily lectures.  Weakness is maybe more of an introduction in lecture to the problem set problems but the TA's office hours were always more than helpful.
Make review sessions more tailored to test
Cormac O'Dea is the strength. He is a fantastic lecturer and made the material very conceptual and relatively easy to understand. Of course, Econ is still a relatively hard subject at times.

Strengths: Very well organized, clear expectations, taught well, ample time for office hours, very helpful TFs, many resources
Weaknesses: Curve can be frustrating especially when aiming for an A; only top 13% can receive an A

Cormac is a great instructor, and he's better than most of the previous course instructors. He's willing to help his students and goes out of his way to engage students in economics. That said, this class is a huge lecture so it's very easy to get lost in the crowd and feel no personal connection with the instructor. I'd recommend going to office hours.

Strength: Content is organized well and this is reflected in the order of the problem sets. There are many resources available to students with misunderstandings.
Weaknesses: Lecture is boring and so large that there is no incentive to pay attention.

Strengths: Economics is actually very interesting. Cormac O'Dea is an adorable human being with a great sense of humor and made the class bearable. There was lots of help available for Psets and studying for exams, however, this availability did not translate into a good grade in economics.

Weaknesses: The teaching fellows. They do not know how to teach economics. Being an economic genius does not translate into knowing how to teach it and that was the case here. There were unnecessarily hard questions on exams that were never covered in class or section that made a lot of people lose points. Additionally, the graders on the exam were entirely to apathetic and didn't understand that this was an introductory microeconomics class.

Improvement: This course makes so much more sense when calculus is used. Please stop avoiding using calculus in this course it makes it so hard to follow. I understand trying to make this course open to everyone by not including calculus, but you're impeding the learning of everyone else when you don't explain that marginal cost is the derivative of cost.

The course is typical of a microeconomics lecture and Professor O'Dea managed to make it more interesting and understandable than I thought it would be. However, section seemed entirely disconnected from what we learned in lecture, which made me confused and made exams unpredictable.

Overall, the large lecture structure of the course sometime made it difficult to remain engaged, but the material was presented well, with a reasonable amount of real-world examples and a few interactive activities to keep the class interesting. It could be improved with the further integration of active participation activities such as surveys.

The course was surprisingly excellent. The biggest strength was Professor O'Dea. He was especially good at explaining the assumptions and shortcomings of the models we learned so that we didn't leave feeling like economics is a myopic field. The weakness is probably the students, many of whom can't wait to get into finance and extort the poor for their personal enrichment.

Strengths - wonderful professor
Weaknesses - lot of content

Strengths: useful course to take for life and jobs. Cormac is actually a fantastic lecturer for someone teaching a class this big. 

Weaknesses: course director seemed quite disorganized at times.
I thought it was boring but it was econ so its okay.
Fairly well organized- but it moved a little fast towards the end. I felt like I was learning so much all at once.
I like how they post the lectures online So it makes it easier to study for exams. I wish the lectures were recorded so you could rewatch them.

Strengths: The level of understanding you gain on what makes you buy what you buy

Weaknesses: Lecture engagement is tough, however, there was a lot of help outside of class through section, office hours, etc.
The strengths of the class are that the material was really interesting, fun to learn, and not too much work. However, sometimes it was unclear what was expected for the tests.
just should be more seminars offered, better TAs, more designated times for question asking in lecture, more written out steps how to do problems

This course's greatest strength is the professor. Cormac O'Dea is a wonderful, funny, and engaging professor. He is a wonderful professor for this course. 

The weaknesses of this course are that the TAs very greatly in quality. It could be improved by a more consistent hiring process.

Professor O'Dea was a great lecturer, and the peer tutoring resources for this class really helped with p-sets. Overall, it felt like this course tried to pack too much info into one basic intro course, and I think that there was a big gap in performance and perceived difficulty of the class between those who had taken an economics class before and those who had no exposure. Providing extra enrichment/review could help to decrease this gap. Also, the lecture slides and format could be more entertaining if it maybe incorporated more videos, polls, etc. to engage the class.

Weaknesses: we could benefit from doing at least one or two of the higher-level application type problems during lecture that we see in the problem sets. I often felt unprepared to complete the problem sets because I didn't have the proper intuition to complete them, despite consistently reviewing the underlying concepts.
Psets and office hours were very helpful to learning the content and Cormac O'dea was a great lecturer.
great lecturer, covered a lot of topics in a short amount of time but all were explained well.
I honestly can't think of any weaknesses, it was taught extremely well.
i liked the style of the course
You learn a lot really fast. Lectures could be more engaging.
Weakness: TAs are hit or miss for section
Great course material and great lecturer!

Strength is the style of teaching and section. I learned a lot and exactly why was tested. I never felt there was a missing link between class and an exam. Professor Odea truly prepared students to answer questions and taught them the material. However, I felt lectured spent a lot of time on rudimentary topics and I got bored often.

I thought this was a pretty good course. Because it is so big I think it can be easy to disengage but Professor O'Dea did a few interactive type activites which I found especially helpful. I didn't find section useful but it is nice that it is not graded.

The way the course was taught DID NOT ALLOW FOR INTUITION TO BE DEVELOPED.  There was a lot of algebra thrown at the class and not a lot of explaining of what those numbers mean.  The parts I understood best were things I learned in high school and on Khan Academy.  Professor would use examples that (it seemed) he would expect the class to be confused by.  Not conducive to learning.

Strengths: Decent workload. Fair exams
Weaknesses: The psets were graded out of 5... 1 mistake meant getting a 4/5
The lectures were very well organized and presented clearly and the psets were organized in a way that helped to review the material.

Strengths: Competent, engaging, and helpful instructor

Weaknesses: None

Cormac was a great lecturer who kept the class engaged. Problem sets were generally not too hard and there were no major curveballs in the exams. Sometimes though he would discuss examples which would not be on the exam so people began to zone out during that time. Also, section often was very boring and dragged on for a long time. Review sessions were helpful though.

Strength: Great professor and TFs

Weakness: N/A
Section materials are too different from what is on the problem sets
This class is a great introduction to microeconomics and the professor was engaging!
I felt very strong in this class - To improve my weaknesses I should've gone to more office hours
Better TAs next time
The course instructors are excellent.

Strengths:
Cormac O'Dea is a great prof 10/10

Weaknesses:
I wish sections had been structured differently. Rather than slowly go through practice problems, I feel like it would have been more helpful to review the information addressed in class. Although I cannot speak for anyone other than myself, it is incredibly intimidating to ask a question in a 250+ student lecture. So, having the opportunity to ask content-oriented questions in section would have been very useful.
lectures are very boring and not very helpful, teacher teaches in very monotone manner
This course was amazing. Cormac is one of the best lecturers as he was so organized and is so engaging

Strength: Professor was good

Weakness: hard to understand material because lecture was to fast, pset took forever
Cormac is amazing. Take it because of him.
Its very informative. Its a large class so it is hard to get one on one help.

I think that the course gave a good overview of microeconomics, in a way that was relevant both for intended majors and people unfamiliar with econ. The only weakness, which is natural for a large lecture like this, is that it was sometimes hard to stay engaged with all the materail. However, I think Professor O'Dea did a good job bringing in examples to apply the theories and keep students interested in lecture, and I also think a lot of resources where made clearly available for students to seek help.

Strengths: great lecture (s/o to Cormac; it was easy to understand and went at a pace that worked quite well) 

Ehh: it's an intro course: what do you expect? For an intro course, however, I thought it was quite good

Weaknesses: the TAs often were so smart that they didn't really understand how to scale it back and teach some of the more basic concepts
Improve the quality of TFs
Great professor but still sometimes lectures dragged on

Strengths: the knowledge in the course has a strong progression so you first learn the basics and then build on them so it doesnt feel like you just learn the material and then drop it. I also enjoyed the emphasis on real world examples and data analysis that the prof brought. The material was also really well justified and explained.
Weaknesses: if you know basic Econ the class might move kind of slow. Also, minimal focus on mathematics.

Strengths - good broad introduction 
Weaknesses - wide range of difficulty

Strengths: Lecture slides were posted before and after each lecture - this made is easy to pay attention to the Professor's points during lecture rather than  having to make sure everything was copied down. 
Weaknesses: Section practice problems were often difficult and rushed, so sometimes I would leave more confused than when I entered.

Strengths--Not too much work. The professor was also really good and a funny guy. Weaknesses--Lecture, it's hard to stay engaged during class with so many kids, and it can be a little boring at times.
Really great lecture but the sections were not always useful. The sections were brief and lacked any opportunity to explain, in depth, the concepts that were discussed in lecture.
The course had a great deal of support for students. It relies on a committed and great professor which I had this semester.
HAVE CORMAC TEACH IT EVER SEMESTER PLEASE.  BIGGEST STRENGTH OF THE COURSE IS THE PROFESSOR
Lots of material for self study, which was really good

The strength of the class was the clarity with which the material was presented and the straightforwardness of the class. Exam material followed directly from what we'd done in class, for homework, and for review, so I never felt blindsided by material. In general, the course was just well run and well organized. It could be improved by implementing greater variety of teaching methods and student engagement rather than just powerpoint slides for 75 minutes.

A strength of this course was the professor, and course director, and TA's. Professor O'Dea always came prepared to lecture and made an effort to make the lectures interactive, which was great. I also felt that the course director and the TA's were always willingly to help students, and provided wonderful resources like office hours and additional online materials to help with the course material. I really appreciated the strong network of instructors who wanted to help students learn. 

A weakness of this course was the slight disorganization with sections in the first few weeks. At first, there were not enough TA's to teach sections so we had to combine sections and then go to alternative locations for these sections until this issue was fixed later on in the semester. Another weakness of this course is the grading system, in my opinion. I found it stressful to know that the class was graded on a curve, which meant that 1) a certain percentage of students is allocated an A/A-; 2) even if one scored a high raw score on a test, their score was compared to other students' before turned into a final grade (for example, if one scored a 55 out of 60 but the class average was 52, that would put the student at the lower end of the curve despite 55 out of 60 being an A- by traditional percentage calculations). I feel as if this system can be improved by ridding of the grading system, which would create more collaborative, less stressful spirit in the classroom setting. It was also stressful to know that because of the curved grading system, we did not know our final grade until after the term was over. I also wish there was some way for us to know the benchmark of our grades before then.
Instruction was good; discussion sections could have focused more closely on the problem sets.

Strengths: Course was a taught at a fair pace and was truly introductory in terms of not assuming any prior economics knowledge.
Weaknesses: Course was very basically algebraic, and at times it could have been helpful to explain things a bit more mathematically for those with the background calculus knowledge.

Strength: lectures, reviews past material
Weakness: sometimes a little too repetitive

The major strength of this course was the professor. Prof. O'Dea made this course so much more engaging. He was passionate about the material, and his enthusiasm made an incredibly large lecture class very interesting and entertaining. He really tried to connect with the students, and he certainty made what could be a very dry subject quite fascinating. The major weakness would be the TAs. Many did not effectively communicate the major concepts to the students. They were quite removed from the course it seemed, and going to section did not help most students.
I think this course would be better served as a 3 day, shorter lecture. A lot of time is spent reviewing and the lectures were long.
The course was engaging and the problems sets helped with comprehension, but I think there could have been more optional practice problems offered.
Very good course

The main strength of this course is the amount of support available, as the TAs, professor, and other students are more than willing to help you understand the course materials. Further, section is available for those who need it. 

The main weakness of this course is the lack of engaging course material - too often the professor would spend too much time explaining simpler concepts at a slow pace rather than delving into interesting applications. Further, the large lecture hall made it hard to pay attention and daunting to ask questions. Tests were also graded subjectively and varied by grader, which made the grades confusing and questionable.
Lectures were amazing, sections not so much

Strengths: Professor O'Dea is a great professor. He's incredibly engaging and really wants his students to succeed. There's also a lot of support from the Econ department and TA's/TF's.

Weaknesses: I really can't think of any, expect for the occasional mistakes in the problem sets.
It was pretty good in my opinon
This courses strengths include many opportunities for help and further understanding, but the weaknesses are that the lectures are taught very quickly and are sometimes challenging to follow.

The strengths were that there were many resources available for practice and further clarification (previous years problem sets, peer tutors, office hours, etc.) 

The weaknesses were that lecture was often presented at a very fast pace and sometimes lacked sufficient clarification before moving on to the next topic.
It was wonderful!
Great class! Really nothing to improve. Cormac rocked

Strengths: Offers a basic introduction to eco 
Weaknesses: grounded too much in quantitative proofs. Even if we didn't understand the theory behind it, we could simply memorize the equations and get the questions right, so the tests were not a true measure of our understanding. 
Improvement: have more qualitative questions that test theoretical understanding.
No weaknesses

I felt that the course was really organized and I liked that there were so many practice exams from previous classes which were available. There aren't many weaknesses in this course. I just wished that people who had already taken micro before took a more advanced class because there were people who already knew all the material and it didn't seem fair.

Strengths: Professor ODea is a fantastic lecturer.

Weaknesses: the TFs were not great teachers, the class was very disorganized.

Cormac was a fantastic professor. However, I found many of the lectures to be rather dull. I am not sure whether this is because of the nature of the material or the structure of the course, but I became rather bored with the class as the semester progressed.

This course was honestly one of my favorites at Yale, a fact I completely attribute to Professor O'Dea's dynamic teaching style. He is very diligent about stopping for questions and conducting a brief review at the start of every class to ensure that our intuitions from class are consistent and permanent. Given the rather strict confines of the ECON 115 class, he was really effective at going at a speed that didn't bore people who understood the concepts, but didn't confuse those who felt more fresh to the concepts being introduced. He gave us a good sampling of more advanced concepts as well in order to prepare us for what to expect at upper levels, while simultaneously ensuring that we had the more basic foundational understandings necessary to succeed at those levels. He understood that, especially in a class of 300 students, there is a diversity of adeptness with the material being taught, and strove to make his class accessible to everyone. 

I do wish that section did more than practice problems, and instead was conducted as a bit more of a review. I also think that if attendance at section were included as part of the grade, more people would show up (I was often one of two or three students that came). Also, I think having occasional quizzes might, while increasing stress a bit, reinforce the ideas from classes effectively. A daily quiz at the end (even an ungraded one!) might be really helpful to test how the lessons from class have been conveyed.

This course is taught very well during the lecture, but the TAs were not very helpful. They simply walked through sample problems, and it would've been more helpful if they could review some of the content in the lecture, as lectures covered a lot of complex content that needed to be reviewed. The readings also could've been more closely related to the lecture content.

great professor

not great TAs

This class is well-structured and taught in a relevant and applicable way. It sometimes seemed that we were expected to know how to extrapolate knowledge learned in class in very different ways on the problem sets, so some in-class examples might be useful, but in general I felt like the psets and tests were consistent and fair. I also thought that the mix of conceptual/theoretical and practical applications was useful for understanding both the broader scheme of economics and society, and the ways in which these ideas are applied. Some more feedback on the psets and tests would have been useful, but I understand that that might not be feasible in such a large class.

Strengths: Cormac O'Dea was a fabulous professor who took material infamous for boring large lecture halls and (almost always) brought it to life; I thought problem sets were well-created/interesting and the tests were fair; strong support system with peer tutors; O'Dea made attempts to connect the material to real life with news articles during some lectures and a great Planet Money podcast that tied in with our coursework -- intro econ courses and instructors should continue to make and further that effort to connect content to the news. Weaknesses: Clarify teaching around algebra and graphs by listing out key equations and types of algebra/graphing problems students must solve; Lack of day-to-day preparation - we had problem sets due once a week but no weekly assignments outside of this; I could have bought and prepared for our lectures with an introductory micro textbook if I really wanted, but I think giving students a website/online resource/short summaries as simple assigned reading before class (15 mins before each class, let's say) would help me keep my econ mind sharp throughout the week and would prime me to absorb lectures more than just glancing at pre-posted slides before hand; sections are a little monotonous
I liked the course and the material that was covered was fair. I thought the amount of time spent on each portion of the course was well divided.
Good course, does not need improvement.
good class if you want an introduction to economics, but the material was pretty dry

I particularly appreciated the balance between theory and applications in the lectures that helped me understand the practical context for what we had learned and showed examples of fitting real life into economic models. Sections and problem sets were key for being really prepared for the exams -- while group work can be helpful, it's also important to try to solve the problems on your own. The course did a good job keeping math prerequisites to a minimum, though applying a little bit of calculus to understand marginal changes would have been helpful. The short unit on market failures at the end of the semester seemed insufficient given the importance of this topic to the practical applications of economics.
Good for a lecture

strength: good lecturer, nice to have all the old review material from past classes on the canvas website

weaknesses: the beginning and end of class seemed skip-able

This course is overall amazing. I think sometimes things could be clarified the first time better (instead of going more in depth in the review slides) but overall it was great. One thing was I would really appreciate if the calculus methods were explained to us (because for people who took calc it makes it so much easier to understand!!!). Other than the calc thing though, no complaints.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but I can only speak for my experience with prof. O'Dea.
If you're looking for a QR credit, this is way better than any math class at Yale.
No
Yes, I think its a good course for anyone considering econ to take.  Also good opportunity to test yourself in a big lecture course.
Definitely
Yes if you want intro to micro

Yes, Econ is a very Yale class. When taken in lecture, you usually know a lot of people to work and study with. The curve also makes it easy to not really sweat making a decent grade. I had never taken Econ before and walked away with a good understanding and feel confident to take macroeconomics. Weekly set, 2 midterms and a final, so not an overbearing workload.

Yes, 100%. This has been one of my favorite courses at Yale because of how well organized and taught it is. There are an insane amount of resources and expectations for students are clear cut. Even though it is a large lecture (250+ students), I was able to form relationships with my professor and TF. Like any other course, you get out as much as you put in. In my case, I enjoyed it because I put a lot in. Also my first Microeconomic course! I may major in Economics because of how much I liked it.
Yes. This class gives you a basic understanding of microeconomics. It is a great way to get social science credit for STEM majors.
Yes, because it's not too challenging but doesn't feel like a gut. You're still learning a lot, but the workload is pretty chill and it's not mind-boggling content.

No, I would not recommend this course to someone else unless they were good at math or had a good background in economics. There is a lot of help for this course but not in the way that there needs to be help. Like even if you get help you will still struggle on exams. Class time can get incredibly boring with explanations for the math process instead of just giving us the formula and connecting it to the concept. A lot of my time was wasted in economics.
